content:
I'm reading Construction 2.0.0.1 in Lurie's Higher Algebra:

Let (C,⊗)(C, \otimes)(C,⊗) be a symmetric monoidal category. We define a new category C⊗C^\otimesC⊗ as follows:

(i) An object of C⊗C^\otimesC⊗ is a finite sequence of objects of CCC, which we will denote by [C1,…,Cn][C_1, \dots, C_n][C1​,…,Cn​].

(ii) A morphism from [C1,…,Cn][C_1, \dots, C_n][C1​,…,Cn​] to [C1′,…,Cm′][C'_1, \dots, C'_m][C1′​,…,Cm′​] in C⊗C^\otimesC⊗ consists of a subset S⊆{1,…,n}S \subseteq \{1, \dots, n\}S⊆{1,…,n}, a map of finite sets α ⁣:S→{1,…,m}\alpha \colon S \to \{1, \dots, m\}α:S→{1,…,m}, and a collection of morphisms {fj ⁣:⨂α(i)=jCi→Cj′}1≤j≤m\{f_j \colon \bigotimes_{\alpha(i) = j} C_i \to C'_j\}_{1 \leq j \leq m}{fj​:⨂α(i)=j​Ci​→Cj′​}1≤j≤m​ in the category CCC.

(iii) Suppose we are given morphisms f ⁣:[C1,…,Cn]→[C1′,…,Cm′]f \colon [C_1, \dots, C_n] \to [C'_1, \dots, C'_m]f:[C1​,…,Cn​]→[C1′​,…,Cm′​] and g ⁣:[C1′,…,Cm′]→[C1′′,…,Cℓ′′]g \colon [C'_1, \dots, C'_m] \to [C''_1, \dots, C''_\ell]g:[C1′​,…,Cm′​]→[C1′′​,…,Cℓ′′​] in C⊗C^\otimesC⊗, determining subsets S⊆{1,…,n}S \subseteq \{1, \dots, n\}S⊆{1,…,n} and T⊆{1,…,m}T \subseteq \{1, \dots, m\}T⊆{1,…,m} together with maps α ⁣:S→{1,…,m}\alpha \colon S \to \{1, \dots, m\}α:S→{1,…,m} and β ⁣:T→{1,…,ℓ}\beta \colon T \to \{1, \dots, \ell\}β:T→{1,…,ℓ}. The composite g∘fg \circ fg∘f is given by the subset U=α−1T⊆{1,…,n}U = \alpha^{-1} T \subseteq \{1, \dots, n\}U=α−1T⊆{1,…,n}, the composite map β∘α ⁣:U→{1,…,ℓ}\beta \circ \alpha \colon U \to \{1, \dots, \ell\}β∘α:U→{1,…,ℓ}, and the maps
⨂β∘α(i)=kCi≃⨂β(j)=k⨂α(i)=jCi→⨂Cj′→Ck′′\bigotimes_{\beta \circ \alpha (i) = k} C_i \simeq \bigotimes_{\beta(j) = k} \bigotimes_{\alpha(i) = j} C_i \to \bigotimes_{} C'_j \to C''_k⨂β∘α(i)=k​Ci​≃⨂β(j)=k​⨂α(i)=j​Ci​→⨂​Cj′​→Ck′′​
for 1≤k≤ℓ1 \leq k \leq \ell1≤k≤ℓ.

I'm confused by this composition rule though. Consider Set\mathsf{Set}Set with its cartesian monoidal structure. We can consider a function f ⁣:A×B→Cf \colon A \times B \to Cf:A×B→C to be a morphism [A,B]→[C,D][A,B] \to [C,D][A,B]→[C,D] is Set×\mathsf{Set}^\timesSet×, and also a function g ⁣:C×D→Eg \colon C \times D \to Eg:C×D→E as one [C,D]→[E][C,D] \to [E][C,D]→[E]. But what is the composite [A,B]→[E][A,B] \to [E][A,B]→[E]? g(f(a,b),?)g(f(a,b),?)g(f(a,b),?) doesn't make sense to me.
I think you're right. Perhaps he forgot to state that α\alphaα needs to be a surjective map?
If α\alphaα and β\betaβ are surjective, the composition rule checks out.

I don't think α\alphaα needs to be surjective! But we need to read Lurie's definition carefully when α\alphaα is not surjective, and use the fact that the tensor product of an empty set of objects is the unit object.

Joe Moeller said:

Let (C,⊗)(C, \otimes)(C,⊗) be a symmetric monoidal category. We define a new category C⊗C^\otimesC⊗ as follows:

(i) An object of C⊗C^\otimesC⊗ is a finite sequence of objects of CCC, which we will denote by [C1,…,Cn][C_1, \dots, C_n][C1​,…,Cn​].

(ii) A morphism from [C1,…,Cn][C_1, \dots, C_n][C1​,…,Cn​] to [C1′,…,Cm′][C'_1, \dots, C'_m][C1′​,…,Cm′​] in C⊗C^\otimesC⊗ consists of a subset S⊆{1,…,n}S \subseteq \{1, \dots, n\}S⊆{1,…,n}, a map of finite sets α ⁣:S→{1,…,m}\alpha \colon S \to \{1, \dots, m\}α:S→{1,…,m}, and a collection of morphisms {fj ⁣:⨂α(i)=jCi→Cj′}1≤j≤m\{f_j \colon \bigotimes_{\alpha(i) = j} C_i \to C'_j\}_{1 \leq j \leq m}{fj​:⨂α(i)=j​Ci​→Cj′​}1≤j≤m​ in the category CCC.

[....]

Consider Set\mathsf{Set}Set with its cartesian monoidal structure. We can consider a function f ⁣:A×B→Cf \colon A \times B \to Cf:A×B→C to be a morphism [A,B]→[C,D][A,B] \to [C,D][A,B]→[C,D] in Set×\mathsf{Set}^\timesSet× [...]

How is that a morphism in Set×\mathsf{Set}^\timesSet×? What's your map of finite sets α:{A,B}→{C,D}\alpha : \{A,B\} \to \{C,D\} α:{A,B}→{C,D}?

I'll guess α\alphaα maps both AAA and BBB to CCC. Then to get a morphism we need a function f1 ⁣:A×B→Cf_1 \colon A \times B \to Cf1​:A×B→C and also a morphism f2 ⁣:1→Df_2 \colon 1 \to Df2​:1→D. Here 111 is the product of the set of objects that map to DDD... which is the empty set.

I think this should solve your problem.
Of course! I have fallen for an old trap.
Interesting construction, what is it being used for?

The category constructed (along with an opfibration to Fin∗\mathsf{Fin}_*Fin∗​ that's not to hard to see) carries enough data to recover the original monoidal category. This characterization is the "right" way to think about symmetric monoidal categories if you want to jump up to (∞,1)(\infty, 1)(∞,1)-symmetric monoidal categories.

John Baez said:

How is that a morphism in Set×\mathsf{Set}^\timesSet×? What's your map of finite sets α:{A,B}→{C,D}\alpha : \{A,B\} \to \{C,D\} α:{A,B}→{C,D}?

I'll guess α\alphaα maps both AAA and BBB to CCC. Then to get a morphism we need a function f1 ⁣:A×B→Cf_1 \colon A \times B \to Cf1​:A×B→C and also a morphism f2 ⁣:1→Df_2 \colon 1 \to Df2​:1→D. Here 111 is the product of the set of objects that map to DDD... which is the empty set.

I think this should solve your problem.

Oh, you're right. I was completely glossing over this, thinking DDD just gets basically nothing.
